data.title: Book Review: The Sparrow, Mary Doria Russell
data.meta_description: A short book review of "The Sparrow" by Mary Doria Russell. Mostly spoiler-free.

The Sparrow, Mary Doria Russell

Dates read: January 14, 2024 to February 10, 2024

This year, I committed to reading more science fiction â€” urban over space, but not fully refusing the latter. The Sparrow was recommended to me by some writing friends, after they learned that I enjoy what I called â€œthe Jesuit take on spirituality.â€ The crossing over of theology, philosophy, and sociology with alien societies was extra appealing to me, and so I ventured in.

The book is about a Jesuit scientific expedition (i.e. organized by the Society of Jesus, with a crew not entirely made up of Jesuit priests) to the planet of Rakhat, after a radio broadcast is discovered and interpreted to be alien songs. The theological underline of this was that â€œGod has other childrenâ€ and that we had a duty to get to know them and love them.

Afterward, when telling my partner or friends about it, I lovingly explained the book as â€œJesuits in space.â€ Iâ€™ve since been delighted to learn that â€œJesuits in spaceâ€ or â€œpriests making first contactâ€ is a well-explored niche, trope or subgenre.

Most of my friends thought â€œJesuits in spaceâ€ was a comical summary. I did too, before I realized just how heavy the book was going to be, with its spiritual, ethical and existential questions.

I love that Emilio Sandoz, the central protagonist, was a complex priest. Itâ€™s this sort of layeredness that makes me drawn to Jesuit spirituality above other Catholic-Christian theologies. He was sarcastic and stubborn, prone to humor and even inappropriateness around the right people, brilliant and tortured, with a violent past leading into a mystical present. He was a picture-perfect idea of the path to sainthood, and known by his superiors as â€œGodâ€™s best beloved.â€

He was upfront about not necessarily feeling Godâ€™s presence but seeking to know Them anyway, and he let himself be led and transformed by Godâ€™s mysteries. Despite uncertainties with his personal faith, he followed what he believed to be Godâ€™s will, all the way to outer space.

Tragic and traumatizing as the storyâ€™s outcome would be, I appreciated (with a complicated literary approach and not necessarily an empathetic human one) how bold the book was in challenging the concept of Godâ€™s unknowable will.

â€œYou see, that is my dilemma. Because if I was led by God to love God, step by step, as it seemed, if I accept that the beauty and the rapture were real and true, then the rest of it was Godâ€™s will too, and that, gentlemen, is cause for bitterness. But if I am simply a deluded ape who took a lot of old folktales far too seriously, then I brought all this on myself and my companions and the whole business becomes farcical, doesnâ€™t it.

â€œThe problem with atheism, I find, under these circumstances [â€¦] is that I have no one to despise but myself. If, however, I choose to believe that God is vicious, then at least I have the solace of hating God.â€

the character Emilio, reflecting on the tragic events of the book

I love the priestsâ€™ repetition of â€œDeus vult.â€ â€œGod wills it,â€ or in the more casual way they put it, â€œGod likes it that way.â€ They used it when someone couldnâ€™t explain certain natural sciences, like the way time warped in lightspeed, and then it was used against them when someone died of mysterious causes.

â€œYou want a reason?â€ she asked, rounding on him. [â€¦] â€œYou want a reason? Deus vult, pater. God wanted him dead, okay?â€

I adored Sofia Mendez, and came to love Anne Edwards, Jimmy Quinn, Marc Robichaux and the rest. I loved that, even though the book told me from the very beginning that only Emilio Sandoz survived the journey, the book made me fall in love with them all anyway.

I want to emphasize that, despite centering Jesuit priests in the mission, the book is open and tolerant about questioning, about atheism and agnosticism. At several moments, it even raises Judaism â€” the religion into which the author, Mary Doria Russell, converted after leaving the Catholic church at 15. My favorite character after Emilio is a brilliant Jewish woman.

It is not an evangelistic Christian book, but an inquiry into the nature of faith. I can imagine critical agnostics, skepticals and mystics enjoying this where traditional Catholics might possibly find it unnerving.

The story is so challenging and heavy, and many times straight-up dark. I donâ€™t think I could have read this at a different time of my life: for example, if things were going well for me and I was unready to have my world shaken and my faith (or what semblance of it I have) tested.

The Sparrow framed my faithâ€™s questions more intricately than I could ever do for myself. It also honored those questions enough to not answer them for me.

To call it a memorable read is an understatement â€” it was more like scarring.

Overall, The Sparrow is a great book for people who want something challenging and thought-provoking, and who are interested in the social and academic complexities of first contact with other species. Itâ€™s not for people who want something clean and neatly delivered.

Will I be reading Children of God, the sequel? Absolutely. But not soon. I need to lie down for a few months first.
